prompt.p: A 64-year-old woman presents complaining of severe abdominal pain, diarrhoea, nausea and vomiting. On examination she is dehydrated, pulse 122 beats/min, blood pressure 95/65 mmHg, respiration rate 22, oxygen saturation 97% and temperature 37°C. Her abdomen is diffusely tender and per rectal examination is normal. Chest examination reveals fine bibasal crepitations and normal heart sounds.
What medication is the cause of the patient's presentation?

modalFeedback.p: Option C (Metformin) is Correct. Metformin can rarely cause lactic acidosis which requires withdrawal of this treatment. It can occur in the presence of renal impairment, dehydration, shock, infection or myocardial infarction.
Option A (Alendronate) is Incorrect. Alendronate is a bisphosphonate that is used in osteoporosis. Tablets can cause erosion of the gastrointestinal tract, e.g. oesophagitis or gastric ulceration.

Option B (Carbimazole) is Incorrect. Agranulocytosis is a complication of this medication used to treat hyperthyroidism. Patients are warned to seek medical attention if they become ill with symptoms and sign of infection.
Option D (Prednisolone) is Incorrect. Prednisolone is an cause iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome.
Option E (Thyroxine) is Incorrect. Levothyroxine can cause symptoms and signs of thyrotoxicosis.
